docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-18 Final U.S. Draft at U.N. Gives Iraq a Last Chance The United States presented the Security Council with its final proposal for a resolution to give Iraq a last chance to disarm through rigorous weapons inspections or face American-led war. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Women who take hormone therapy after menopause and continue with it for 10 years or more may have a reduced risk of Alzheimer's disease, researchers report. But scientists, including the study's lead investigator, caution that the study's findings are suggestive, not definitive, in part because of the study's design and because relatively few women who took part developed the disease. For now, medical experts say, there is not enough evidence to tell women, even those at high risk of Alzheimer's, to take estrogen to lower their risk.

headline.main: Study Suggests Long-Term Hormone Therapy May Reduce Alzheimer's Risk for Women

docs.abstract: Study by Dr John C Breitner finds that women who take hormone therapy after menopause and continue it for ten years or more may have reduced risk for Alzheimer's disease; cautions about small size of study, in Cache County, Utah, warning that finding does not warrant prescribing of hormones for this purpose (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: November BESOTTED -- Holly Angell Hardman wrote, directed and stars in a fantasy about a sorceress who arrives in a Cape Cod fishing hamlet intending to cast love spells on the villagers. The ensemble cast includes Amy Wright, Liam Waite, Susan Gibney, Jim Chiros and Richard Cox. Opened Friday.

headline.main: Santa, James Bond and Other Old Friends

byline.original: By ANITA GATES (Compiled with the assistance of SUZANNE O'CONNOR)

docs.lead_paragraph: YOU might never know it from the nightly news, but the election on Tuesday is particularly important for older Americans. How the vote goes for the House and the Senate will help determine the kind of prescription drug coverage that retirees may receive, and whether conservatives can continue their drive to at least partly privatize the Social Security system. The new Congress will also face deep problems in Medicare, as well as the problem of the millions of people without any health insurance -- including many older Americans who are not yet eligible for Medicare.

headline.main: Older Voters Hear More Than War Drums

docs.abstract: Fred Brock column contends that despite scant news coverage, economic and social issues dominate older voters' thinking about many coming election races around nation (M)
